utterances: Well, the distance is a whole different game.
You know, and in part, it's a different game because horses in America today aren't bred to go a mile and a half.
You know, I was looking back at the 1980s, the horses who won the Kentucky Derby, every horse had like a solid mile-and-a-half runner, and the first two generations, it was pedigree.

And so when horses, you know, like from the '70s and that - from that era, you know, went into the Belmont, they were pretty much, you know, mostly equipped, you know, to, you know, to run the distance.
Now, nobody is bred for a mile and a half.
And so when horses get into this race even if they look good finishing it at a mile and a quarter in the Derby, as I'll Have Another did, you know, it's a real unknown factor.
I mean, it's kind of a crapshoot to know who is, you know, who's got the genes to go the distance.
The other aspect of it is that the horse's jockey is unfamiliar with Belmont Park, which is, I think, the only track in the country that's a mile and a half.
I take my horses by - well, I used to be an exercise girl back in my youth.
And I study their genetics, and then I usually go by picking the colors of the jockey.
(LAUGHTER)
The silks?
And happy Labor Day to you.
I think it's very important to act promptly.
It's important that we get the verification situation straightened out immediately and, secondly, that we get back to the table again to talk about tactical nuclear weapons.
Those talks will not occur until we ratify the relatively modest new START treaty.
And I say relatively modest because it makes only small adjustments in the numbers of nuclear warheads and carriers and what have you, but it does get the process back on track.
It's not on track now, and that is dangerous for our national security.

There are some newly elected members of the Senate, like Rand Paul from Kentucky, who have expressed some concern over, you know, whether the treaty could limit American anti-missile deployment overseas.
Do you think those concerns are legitimate?
No, I don't believe that they are.

And we've had 15 hearings of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and all the testimony has been very clearly that we are not inhibited in any way in creating missile defense, whether it be based in Europe or based in the United States or based anywhere.
I think that's a very important consideration.
And I'm hopeful we'll have an opportunity to visit with Senator Paul and with others as they are coming in.
Senator Lugar, in which areas do you see daylight between congressional Republicans and the administration when it comes to foreign policy?
Well, for the moment, I would say that there is a very considerable degree of cooperation.
In Afghanistan, Republicans have given very strong support on Afghanistan.
I would not suggest that Democrats have not given support, too, but the fact is that this has been much more of a debate within the Democratic Party.
That President Obama has always perceived was a severe limitation on his ability to conduct foreign policy in Afghanistan.
You have been described as one of the few remaining statesmen in the U.S.
Senate.
I'm wondering if you're concerned at all about the difference in basic foreign policy perspectives between some of the so-called Tea Party candidates and more traditional Republicans like yourself.
On foreign policy issues, it seems to me that many of the Tea Party candidates have views that I would think are very similar to my own.
The campaign we've just been through, as a matter of fact, did not have much to say about foreign policy.
Well, I mean, some candidates have talked about how the president has gone around the world apologizing for America and so on and so forth.
I mean, would you agree with that?
Well, I really wouldn't characterize the president as apologizing for America, although I understand that some feel that he might be accused of doing this sort of thing.
But at the same time, I think as members from the Tea Party come to the Congress, they will face the same worldwide problems the rest of us have.
There are, I think, no doctrinaire lines right now with regard to how to solve extremely complex problems that really have defied solutions for quite a while.
The next two years, will it be gridlock?
No, I don't perceive gridlock, certainly, in foreign policy.
I believe that the American people will require and maybe demand that we make headway on our domestic economic affairs.
But likewise, they will have an eye out for dangers of this country and the world.
They will demand that we take that responsibility, which we should.
That's Indiana Senator Richard Lugar.
He is the ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Senator Lugar, thank you so much.
Thank you very much for this opportunity.
Now, if there's one person who knows how to work in and out of power, it's former Democratic Senator Tom Daschle.
He was both a majority leader and a minority leader.
And when I called him up this past week, he explained that even in the most partisan of environments, there are always ways to find compromise.
You know, Mitch McConnell has already said that his number one priority is defeating the president.
I think that's a strange number one priority for a national political leader.
But if that's it, I'd like to know what his fourth and fifth priorities are because maybe his fourth and fifth and President Obama's third and fourth actually might overlap.
Let's talk about the domestic agenda.
Where do you see the president and congressional Republicans working together?
I think the trade, I think the economy, I think tax policy.
There's an array of things that surprise most people about health care that we could agree to, including more information technology, finding better ways to ensure we keep people healthy.
Those are kinds of things that I think are worthy of far more discussion than they've gotten today.
All we've talked about so far is repeal, and that's going nowhere.
But it seems as if there's no question that both President Obama and the congressional Republicans will have to compromise on the principles.
See, I don't think it's compromising on principle.
I don't think either side is capable of - or even should have to do that.
But I do think when it comes to public policy, you can apply principles in a way that allow for common ground.

Do you think the president should adopt, you know, the so-called triangulation strategy that Bill Clinton used, you know, where he effectively played elements of his own party off of congressional Republicans?
Well, I'm not - I've never been comfortable with that term because I think it's so pejorative.
The fundamental question can be, can we include?
Inclusion is key.
If people feel included, if they feel as if they can be invested in something that they really can point to as an accomplishment, I think there's some real opportunities.
But the volatility this past month has made him change his strategy.
So how would, you know, President Obama do that, do what Clinton did?
I mean, what issues, specific issues, do you think he ought to choose?
Well, first is the process.
I would love to see some Camp David sessions.
I'd love to see some weekly meetings down at the White House, intense meetings on probably the first and most important thing is the economy.
How can we continue to improve, how can we build, how can we bring down the unemployment levels, and what can Republicans, Democrats do together to make that happen?
It's widely known that you urged the president to hold more private meetings with top Republicans, particularly with Mitch McConnell.
That apparently didn't happen until the president was in office for 18 months.
I mean, will President Obama have to, you know, sort of schmooze more and slap backs more with congressional Republicans in order to get things done?
Well, I don't know that schmoozing necessarily is what he needs to do.
But I do think you have to build relationships.
You know, legislative work is built in part on trust.
And trust is built on better communication.
And better communication is built on better chemistry.
And the only way you achieve better chemistry is when you've got people in the room that begin the dialogue.
And that's really what has to happen.
We've got to see more dialogue.
Tom Daschle, you know what it's like particularly behind the scenes.
I was surprised to learn recently that at the height of the Lewinsky hearings, Bill Clinton used to have Trent Lott over all the time for private meetings, for coffee.
What does the public not know about what happens behind closed doors?
I mean, does the president have a pretty civil relationship with some of these top Republicans that we just don't see?
Well, I don't think we see as much as I wish you could because I think a lot does go on.
And, you know, the president got a lot of criticism for not having one-on-ones with the leadership.

But I'm telling you, I know for a fact that he's had a lot of occasions where he's had real opportunities to meet with the leadership in small groups, to have discussions, serious discussions, about issues that this country need to address.
So that needs to go on.
But I don't think there's enough of it.
I think we have to do a better job at relationship-building than what we've done so far.
That's former Senate Democratic leader Tom Daschle.
Senator, thank you so much.
